Sunway College Kathmandu, a leading AI college in Nepal, offers a specialized Bachelor Degree in Data Science and Artificial Intelligence.

Sunway College Kathmandu is working in academic partnership with Birmingham City University, UK offering specialized undergraduate course in data science and artificial intelligence, BSc(Hons) Computer Science with Artificial Intelligence. The university ranks 601-800 as per Times Higher Education World Rankings 2024.

Birmingham City University (BCU) is a leading UK university renowned for its strong industry links and focus on practical learning. Ranked 601-800 in the Times Higher Education World Rankings 2024, BCU boasts a diverse student body of over 31,000 individuals from more than 100 countries. Located in the heart of Birmingham, a vibrant and dynamic city, BCU offers a unique learning environment that blends academic excellence with real-world experience.

With over 31,000 students from over 100 countries, BCU is a large and diverse university set in the heart of Birmingham with a focus on practice-based learning. BCU puts students at the heart of everything they do, giving them the best opportunities for future success.

We are those who understand the importance of aligning your passion to your profession. It will help you to identify with your areas of strength, weakness, opportunity and threat, a SWOT and also guide you towards the right job at the end through placement day.

Now, putting our professional suit on, Since its establishment in the year 2010, a 13 year history, Sunway college has been providing academic excellence to produce highly skilled human resources of IT and business-oriented degrees. We are dedicated to mint both academic and professional standards of our students, the Sunwayians. With above 90% placement of alumni ,they are actively working in government sectors, private institutes, entrepreneurship and in international market. With that being said, we are introducing Digital marketing and Data Science with a bigger vision to cater the global demand that enables to built the top 10% skilled-manpower of the future.

Working with multiple international universities has given us a peak on their education system and that has inspired us to make our own system better. Today, we are academically partnered with Birmingham City University (BCU), UK.
A curious mind with 21st century skills and a zest of a learner is someone who we have been looking for. If you know you are the one, Start With Sunway.

The education sector could not be left unaffected by the current wave of modernization and digitization. In keeping with this philosophy, we have introduced one of the leading edge and entrepreneurship-focused "Birmingham City University" to Nepal, to serve students seeking an affordable international education. I'm confident that the academic collaboration with Birmingham City University will benefit local students, employers, and the community as a whole. Our current focus is on awarding undergraduate degrees to students, but we intend to expand to other programs as needed in the future to meet demand. The academic partnership with “Birmingham City University” will soon offer more doors for opportunities to support additional programs. Shortening the gap and inheriting skills to be future-ready requires growth in both mindset and knowledge. Through a holistic approach, we provide support to the students for their overall development and uphold the environment that tends to their physical, emotional, and social wellbeing. Sunway College also offers industrial training to get students ready for the industry and to create a skilled workforce. I urge all future graduate and undergraduate students, along with their parents, to think about Sunway College as a high-quality, well-known, and affordable education institution.

In the past few decades, we have seen significant advancements in the usage of social media platforms which have fundamentally altered customer behavior and patterns. This has all been possible due to the current wave of digitalization and can be marked as the beginning of the digital era. The most striking outcome of the digital revolution is the amount of data that is now collected and analyzed leading to an information explosion and the creation of more and more data-driven platforms. For a country like Nepal, Digital Marketing and Data Science can be a fantastic field to start a career where interest in business is growing and information technology is on the rise. So, to provide a head start to the students, Sunway College in academic partnership with “Birmingham City University” is providing programs to develop highly competitive human capital, be abreast with modern technologies and be socially responsible towards the community. The limitless scope and vast reach of these programs enable students to guarantee their futures globally. Since its Establishment in 2010, Sunway College has been successful in providing the community with a quality, qualified, and responsible workforce that is resolving issues in the real world and making significant economic contributions in the process This academic collaboration is a perfect match between an institution based in Nepal with a global vision and an institution based in the UK with an international outlook and exposure.

Sunway College Kathmandu, a leading AI college in Nepal, offers a specialized Bachelor Degree in Data Science and Artificial Intelligence. As one of the top AI colleges in Nepal, we are dedicated to mint academic and professional standards in our students who will become a believer in change, responsible and innovative after the completion of the course.

Sunway College is affiliated with Birmingham City University (BCU) which is recognized as one of the most promising academic institutions in the United Kingdom. The academic collaboration with BCU offers graduate students numerous opportunities and exposure in the international market.

We adopt an internationally recognized L-T-W (Lecture, Tutorial, and Workshop) teaching approach which focuses on the practicality and applicability of learning. Through a holistic approach, our academic program is designed to assist students in integrating their knowledge into real-world circumstances.

Sunway College provides students with a range of scholarship programs in addition to reasonable tuition rates to support students financially. Sunway College also awards scholarships based on students’ athletic abilities and talents.
Sunway College Kathmandu (in an academic partnership with Birmingham City University) offers experience-oriented international Bachelors degrees in Artificial Intelligence and Data Science.
Birmingham City University is located in Birmingham, United Kingdom, and is featured in the best 1000 universities in the world, according to the most well-known international university rankings.

As per 2022, World University Rankings by Times Higher Education that uses 13 performance indicators, Birmingham City University is ranked 501-600 and is positioned as 12th out of the 100 UK universities ranked. Birmingham City University is also ranked 90th in the QS World University rankings 2022, maintaining the position of the top 100 universities globally and as the top 14th university amongst UK universities. Shanghai Jiao Tong University World Rankings ranked Birmingham as being in the top 101 – 150 (calculated rank 126th) out of 500 universities, establishing us as 12th out of the 36 UK universities to appear in the top 500.

You can study AI at various local universities, local university colleges and foreign affiliated colleges in Nepal. The course offered at Sunway College Kathmandu is BSc(Hons) Computer Science with Artificial Intelligence which specializes in data science and artificial intelligence.
Birmingham City University ranks 501 – 600 globally as per Times Higher Education 2024.
A degree from a top university is recognized worldwide, opening doors to international opportunities.
Yes, the courses offered by Sunway College Kathmandu are approved by the Ministry of Education, Nepal.
Yes, the courses offered by Sunway College Kathmandu are certified equivalence by Tribhuwan University.
All +2 stream students (Science, Management, Humanities, Education and others) can apply for the program having met the eligibility criteria mentioned under the program.

Students who do not meet the entry requirements, can still apply to study the course. The application submitted shall be verified by the Course Committee at BCU and can be approved on a case by case basis.
Yes, the program includes a dedicated professional placement year.

We have a dedicated placement cell headed by Khushal Regmi, Professional Placement Coordinator who is responsible for collaborating with the industry to bring professional placement opportunities to the students. Students may also seek placement opportunities on their own and shall receive support from the placement cell during the process. The placement cell also organizes various skill training sessions that helps students to meet the entry level standards for the industry.
Yes, scholarships are available based on merit and economic condition.
You can fill out the admission form here: or contact the Admissions Department at admission@sunway.edu.np or 9823047066.
There are two enrollment intakes, Autumn and Spring intakes.
Sunway College Kathmandu is located Behind Maitidevi Temple, Maitidevi, Kathmandu, Nepal.

The available courses at Sunway are:

BSc (Hons) Computer Science With Artificial Intelligence (AI) in academic partnership with Birmingham City University, UK.  (Approved)
BSc(Hons) Business Information Technology (Approval in process - expected to run by Autumn 2025)
BSc(Hons) Cybersecurity (Approval in process - expected to run by Autumn 2025)
MSc Artificial Intelligence (Approval in process - expected to run by Autumn 2025)
The Sunway AI Scholarship Award is offered by Sunway College Kathmandu to support outstanding students pursuing a BSc(Hons) Computer Science with Artificial Intelligence based on a scholarship test.

The Sunway AI Scholarship Award is determined post admissions. The student must have achieved the following:

Completed Grade 12 with a minimum CGPA of 3.0 (or equivalent)
Met English proficiency requirements (Grade B in Grade 12 English + BCU EPT 5.5 or equivalent recognized English test)
Attended Early Bird Admissions Classes  
Settled all admission fees at Sunway College Kathmandu
The application deadline for the Sunway AI Scholarship Award for Sprint 2025 Intae is March 14, 2025.

100% Scholarship: Based on Scholarship Test and Interview (March 30th & 31st, 2025)
50% Scholarships: Based on Scholarship Test and Interview (March 30th & 31st, 2025)
30% Scholarships: Based on admission documents and interview

100% Scholarship: Covers college semester fees (excluding admission fees, induction/ECA/CCA fees, annual fees, and university fees)
50% Scholarships: Covers 50% of college semester fees (excluding admission fees, induction/ECA/CCA fees, annual fees, and university fees)
30% Scholarships: Covers 30% of college semester fees (excluding admission fees, induction/ECA/CCA fees, annual fees, and university fees)
Maintaining satisfactory academic performance as per the scholarship policy and college regulations is crucial for scholarship renewal.
Failure to meet the academic performance standards may result in the revocation of the scholarship award.

Strong foundation in Computer Science
Focus on key AI topics like Machine Learning, Deep Learning, Natural Language Processing
Industry-relevant skills development
Professional placement year for practical experience
Individual Honours Project for in-depth research and application

Grade 12 completion with a minimum CGPA of 3.0 (or equivalent)
Meeting English proficiency requirements (Grade B in Grade 12 English + BCU EPT 5.5 or equivalent recognized English test)

After completing the course, you may choose to work as a Software Developer, Software Engineer, Web Developer, Computer Programmer, Machine Learning Engineer, Data Scientist, Artificial Intelligence Engineer and many more!
Yes, the course offers a 9-month placement to students as part of the Professional Placement Year. The college also has a dedicated placement cell.
You can talk to Mr. Khushal Regmi, who heads the placement cell at Sunway College in the capacity of the Professional Placement Coordinator.
After the completion of the second year, students must undergo a placement year where they are hired by companies as interns for at least 9 months.
Students are often hired as interns based on their performance by the college during their academic journey at the college. You can work with the IT department, IoT and Research Lab at the college.

The class schedule is released by the Registry Timetable and Examination Department at the beginning of each semester and updated as required. The classes usually run from 7 AM to 1 PM. Additional classes may be offered on a case by case basis.

Yes. The official student body at Sunway College Kathmandu is Sunway Student Representative Council. The council has student representatives from all batches and the executive members of the council run various clubs at Sunway.

Sunway Student Representative Council partners with DataCamp to offer Data Fellowship to students from all over Nepal. You can visit their website and subscribe to their social media accounts to stay updated regarding the data fellowship openings or simply inquire at datafellowship@sunway.edu.np.

Students are required to mandatorily learn research writing right from the inception of their course and have the opportunity to work in the research lab alongside dedicated research assistants and professors at the college. The college also provides ample opportunities for students to collaborate with industry experts or researchers to work on various projects.

In a move that has sparked significant discussion across various sectors, the Nepalese government recently presented the Social Media Council Bill, 2081 BS in the National Assembly. Tabled by the Minister for Communications and Information Technology, Prithvi Subba Gurung, the Bill aims to regulate the growing use of social media platforms, holding users and operators accountable for their actions. While the government cites its goal of promoting social goodwill, cultural tolerance, and good governance, there are growing concerns about how this Bill will impact students, particularly in terms of their freedom of expression and online engagement.

Understanding the Social Media Council Bill, 2081 BSThe bill seeks to establish clear guidelines for social media operators and users, focusing on ensuring a safe and secure digital environment. Among its key provisions, it outlines the following:Licensing for Digital Platforms: Companies or institutions operating digital platforms will need to obtain a license, valid for two years, to run social media sites in Nepal. Failure to comply with the regulations could lead to the revocation of their operating license.

Content Regulations: The Bill targets cyberbullying, identity theft, misinformation, hate speech, deep fake videos, and other harmful digital behaviors. It also aims to control the spread of content that could jeopardize national peace, security, or sovereignty.

Fines and Penalties: Users who engage in harmful online activities such as trolling, spreading false information, or engaging in online harassment could face fines of up to Rs 500,000. This would affect students who are active on social media platforms, potentially limiting their ability to express themselves freely.
How Will This Affect Nepalese Students?

Conclusion: Adapting to a New Digital EnvironmentAs Nepal moves forward with the Social Media Council Bill, students will need to adjust to the new reality of a more regulated digital space. While the intent of the Bill is to foster a safer, more secure online environment, students must stay informed about how the new regulations will affect their digital interactions. Understanding the implications of the Bill will help students protect their rights to freedom of expression, navigate the new rules on digital conduct, and continue using social media platforms in a responsible and creative way.

You are interested in Data Science but still don’t have any idea or reason behind choosing Data Science!

Don’t worry because choosing Data Science as an undergraduate major can be a rewarding decision for several reasons. Here are ten compelling reasons why you should consider studying data science at the undergraduate level:
High demand and career opportunities:

Data science abilities are in increasing demand across sectors. A degree in data science gives up a wide range of job prospects in industries such as technology, finance, healthcare, marketing, and more.
Interdisciplinary nature:

Data science combines mathematical, statistical, computer science, and domain-specific knowledge concepts. It provides a well-rounded education that prepares you for various positions and allows you to engage in multidisciplinary projects.
Problem-solving and analytical skills:

Data science teaches you problem-solving and analytical abilities. You’ll learn how to extract, clean, analyze, and understand vast and complicated datasets, allowing you to make data-driven choices and solve real-world challenges.
Competitive edge:

With the rising relevance of data-driven decision-making, having a degree in data science provides you with a competitive advantage in the employment market. Employers respect employees who can successfully deal with data and get insightful conclusions.
Versatility and flexibility:

Data science abilities are adaptable and transferable across domains. A data science education allows you to work in a broad spectrum of areas, whether you’re interested in banking, healthcare, environmental sciences, or any other.
Innovation and impact:

Data science is critical for fostering innovation and making a positive difference. You may help progress technology, corporate strategy, social efforts, and other areas by utilizing the power of data.
Continuous learning and growth:

The subject of data science is continually growing, providing chances for ongoing learning and progress. As a data scientist, you’ll need to keep up with the newest technologies, methodologies, and industry trends to keep your skills current.
Collaboration and teamwork:

Collaboration among professionals from diverse backgrounds, including domain experts, programmers, and analysts, is prevalent in data science initiatives. A degree in data science helps you to improve your collaboration and communication abilities, allowing you to work effectively in diverse teams.
Ethical consideration:

Data science brings fundamental ethical concerns about data privacy, prejudice, and openness. Undergraduate studies in data science provide you with the information and critical thinking skills needed to manage these ethical dilemmas ethically.
Impactful storytelling and visualization:

Data scientists not only evaluate data but also effectively convey their results. You’ll learn how to tell captivating tales using data visualization, making difficult information accessible and entertaining by studying data science.

These considerations illustrate the significance and possible effect of getting an undergraduate degree in data science. When choosing an academic career, keep your interests, talents, and long-term objectives in mind.
We are confident that our guidance and inspiration have played a significant role in your decision to pursue Data Science as a field of study and a potential career path.

Generative AI revolutionizes the creative process by allowing humans to supervise while machines generate. This shift relieves us from tedious, risky, and challenging tasks, enabling us to concentrate on the core aspects of our work: vision, ideas, and purpose. It represents a transformative change in the future of employment.
Importance of Generative AI

Generative AI, like photography and celluloid film, represents an incredible creative revolution. It reduces the necessity for creative skill in painting or singing, just as photography emancipated us from relying entirely on artists to depict the truth.

The influence of Generative AI goes beyond creativity, giving rapid access to clear information and the automatic development of varied material such as news stories, product descriptions, bespoke designs, music, visual effects, and more.
It is redefining not only specialized professions as well as our view of work, as AI models increasingly aid with repetitive or computational activities in the manufacturing process.
How is Generative AI different from other AI?
In contrast to other forms of artificial intelligence, generative AI focuses on producing new material, whereas discriminative AI classifies existing data.

Generative AI is used for picture production, video synthesis, language generation, and music composition. It is one of the subcategories of artificial intelligence that encompasses various activities done by AI systems.

Reactive machines for self-driving cars, limited memory AI for weather forecasting, theory of mind for virtual customer assistance, narrow AI for personalized product suggestions in e-commerce, supervised learning for object identification, unsupervised learning for fraud detection in banking, and reinforcement learning for teaching machines to play games are all examples of these tasks.
Generative AI encompasses several of these areas and continues to grow, with its primary goal being the production of new material, whether writing, graphics, or product suggestions.
How Generative AI works?

To recognize patterns and produce new results, generative AI employs techniques such as neural networks and deep learning algorithms. It learns the basic principles guiding the content by studying a vast dataset.

It generates fresh data by sampling from a previously learned distribution. The model refines the output to fit the desired outcome through a process known as “inference,” making it more realistic and aligned with user preferences.
Generative AI Models
1. Natural Language Model

Natural Language Model is the most well-known model of Generative AI, with ChatGPT making headlines. The majority of the excitement around text-based Generative AI is centered on a model known as GPT-3. It’s a language model created by OpenAI, a research group dedicated to the development and promotion of friendly AI.

For example, while computers cannot “understand” language in the same way that humans can, natural language technologies are becoming more effective at identifying the context and meaning of phrases and words and converting them into suitable responses—and actions.
2. Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs)

Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) are a well-known form of Generative AI. GANs consist of a generator and a discriminator that work together to enhance the generator’s ability to generate realistic data.
Over time, the generator improves its capacity to synthesize lifelike data, resulting in the creation of new items, assets, faces, and even people.
GANs can be utilized for various applications, including generating natural features such as lightning, leaves, roots, eyes, and flowers, as well as seamlessly integrating humans with nature.
Furthermore, in the context of financial fraud detection, GAN models can generate synthetic fraudulent transactions to train fraud detection algorithms.
3. VAE and Anomaly Detection

Variational Autoencoders (VAE) are a major model used for anomaly identification. It entails training the model on a collection of normal data and then utilizing it to detect occurrences that deviate from the norm.

VAE has applications in a variety of fields, including financial fraud detection, discovering defects in manufacturing processes, and detecting network breaches. For example, Google has used VAE to identify network attacks.
Future Prediction
Generative AI will continue to play a critical role in computer graphics, animation, and 3D modeling in the gaming, film, and marketing industries.
It will also be employed in the next decade or so to improve virtual assistants’ and chatbots’ natural language understanding, allowing them to conduct complicated discussions.

In the future, generative AI will help to create realistic simulations in sectors like architecture and engineering, create new materials and products in manufacturing and textile design, and aid in natural language production for news articles, novels, and movie screenplays.
Conclusion

In terms of utility and predictability, generative AI is similar to a camera, acting as a powerful instrument in the hands of people. Just like a camera performs reliably, generative AI follows the same pattern each time it is used.

It enables people to use their skills to generate content, develop new solutions, and explore creative possibilities. Users may leverage the potential of generative AI to improve productivity, accelerate improvements, and stimulate discoveries by understanding and utilizing its consistent nature.

Threads is a social networking software developed by Meta, which created Instagram and Facebook. Threads allow you to see a feed of everything that’s going on with your friends or persons you’re interested in.
You may also upload messages, text, images, and videos. You might also respond to or like messages.
Twitter has increased the number of advertisements that appear after one out of every five postings. An individual has a large number of bot accounts and improper accounts that need to be detected.
Twitter charges for verification, risking fake paid Elon Musk accounts. Limited daily tweets can be viewed unless users pay to increase the limit.
Threads aims to counter negative sentiment toward Twitter meta, explicitly stating no monetization until the app hits a billion users.
They’ve adjusted it so that everyone must have an Instagram account before they’re able to sign up, which has significantly reduced the degree of Bot activity.
Because it’s linked to your Instagram account, you won’t have to pay for verification, and it will automatically transfer from your Instagram to your Threads account.
Threads’ unexpected buzz makes it seem like everyone is already there, a challenge for new platforms.

When one of your Instagram followers signs up for Threads, they automatically follow you, giving the user a huge boost in enthusiasm. As a result, threads seem like this New Haven is like a fresh start on Twitter.

Because of his superb timing and some big-brain marketing, Mark Zuckerberg has become the new People’s Choice hero. They’ve also figured out how to develop an enormous fear of missing out among those on the outside.
Registering quickly for a Threads account earns you a rating, akin to a race assessment.
Twitter’s unique focus on news fosters real-time discussions, allowing users to engage and learn about global events and perspectives.
The app Threads faces a data issue, as it currently does not comply with the strict data laws of the European Union.

The software also introduces the notion of automated status sharing, which allows users to automatically share their activities and locations. Threads intelligently recognize and share information about a user’s current status, such as location, movement, or even the music they are listening to, using powerful AI algorithms.
While these capabilities may raise privacy concerns for some users, the app assures that users control information sharing, emphasizing transparency and consent.
Threads intended to debut in a minimal, stable state for V1, resembling Twitter with deliberate Instagram design aspects.

Moreover, it is appropriately called since users have begun to refer to Threads as strings of messages, and it’s straightforward, with your newsfeed consisting of individuals you follow and those you don’t.
It nails the basics—visually appealing, runs smoothly, almost bug-free—making it a less overwhelming alternative to Twitter.

Have you ever wondered how the TikTok algorithm work? Let us review and understand.
TikTok is addictive. It is so addictive that 9 out of 10 users on TikTok use it daily for hours.
How do we spend hours on TikTok, even if it’s a short-content platform?
Let’s understand how the TikTok “For You” algorithm works. We will also cover how the basic recommendation algorithm works.

Before going in depth on how the TikTok algorithm works, let us understand the metadata. Metadata is the data that provides information about the data. This data helps identify and categorize the content for various backend purposes.

Hashtags are a few phrases attached to the end of the captions so they can help the algorithm understand the content type. The video uploader usually chooses this. Hashtags are better for a new content creator because they help TikTok identify the type of content they’re uploading.

TikToks are frequently associated with music. TikTok made a significant move by using copyrighted music as a streaming platform, allowing creators to attach sounds without fear of copyright infringement. The music we choose for a TikTok video categorizes it as well, making it one of the more important pieces of metadata.

TikTok is slowly increasing its video content duration limit. The platform started with a 15-second video uploaded over 10 minutes today. The length of the video also categorizes it, making it metadata for a TikTok video.
The creator uploading the content is by far the most critical metadata to categorize TikTok videos.
Similarly, other metadata such as uploaded time, location, date, and video quality are a few other examples of metadata for a TikTok video.
When a video is released, TikTok usually sends it to all of its active users at once, who are usually chosen based on the metadata of the video that they are watching.
Implicit ratings are ratings that occur as a result of behavior and cannot be faked by the user. For example, ordering a product from an online store.
A few implicit ratings for TikTok videos are:
View Time:

During the initial video shoot, TikTok closely monitors the average watch duration of the video. There is a trend of looping a TikTok video so that the end can be unnoticed; the clever creator does it so that the watch duration exceeds the actual content duration, signaling the TikTok algorithm.
Video Skips:

A video viewer usually skips a video when they don’t like it. This can be an important signal for TikTok to stop recommending the video that has been skipped and instead recommend some other content category.
Profile Visit
When consumers like the video, they usually visit the creator’s profile. This can count as an implicit rating as the user is indicating that they like the creator and want to consume similar content.
Explicit ratings are the ratings that the user explicitly creates, which means there’s some effort in creating explicit ratings. For example, liking a TikTok video
A few explicit ratings for TikTok videos are:
Likes:
The user usually double-taps when they like the content, this helps to increase the likes count for a video and helps the algorithm.
Comments:
A comment on a video can act as a powerful explicit rating if there is more time and effort required to do so.
Shares:
Shares are also one of the most powerful explicit ratings as it is one of the rarest ratings, and parallelly, it also creates more exposure for the content.
As we have understood all the following terms, now we can understand how TikTok algorithm work to  recommended videos.
Step 1: The user uploads the video, and TikTok takes a few minutes to understand the content based on metadata.
Step 2: TikTok distributes the video to a few active users in order to collect preliminary consumption data.
Step 3: TikTok typically suggests the video to users who are watching other similarly category videos based on implicit and explicit ratings for the video.
Step 4: Unless and until the consumption results begin to decline, TikTok will continue to recommend videos to users.

In conclusion, TikTok is a video-editing app that sends videos to a few active users to collect initial consumption results. Based on implicit and explicit ratings for the video, TikTok usually recommends the content to users who are consuming similar videos. Unless and until the consumption results begin to decline, TikTok will continue to recommend videos to users.

In a move that has sparked significant discussion across various sectors, the Nepalese government recently presented the Social Media Council Bill, 2081 BS in the National Assembly. Tabled by the Minister for Communications and Information Technology, Prithvi Subba Gurung, the Bill aims to regulate the growing use of social media platforms, holding users and operators accountable for their actions. While the government cites its goal of promoting social goodwill, cultural tolerance, and good governance, there are growing concerns about how this Bill will impact students, particularly in terms of their freedom of expression and online engagement.

Understanding the Social Media Council Bill, 2081 BSThe bill seeks to establish clear guidelines for social media operators and users, focusing on ensuring a safe and secure digital environment. Among its key provisions, it outlines the following:Licensing for Digital Platforms: Companies or institutions operating digital platforms will need to obtain a license, valid for two years, to run social media sites in Nepal. Failure to comply with the regulations could lead to the revocation of their operating license.

Content Regulations: The Bill targets cyberbullying, identity theft, misinformation, hate speech, deep fake videos, and other harmful digital behaviors. It also aims to control the spread of content that could jeopardize national peace, security, or sovereignty.

Fines and Penalties: Users who engage in harmful online activities such as trolling, spreading false information, or engaging in online harassment could face fines of up to Rs 500,000. This would affect students who are active on social media platforms, potentially limiting their ability to express themselves freely.
How Will This Affect Nepalese Students?

Conclusion: Adapting to a New Digital EnvironmentAs Nepal moves forward with the Social Media Council Bill, students will need to adjust to the new reality of a more regulated digital space. While the intent of the Bill is to foster a safer, more secure online environment, students must stay informed about how the new regulations will affect their digital interactions. Understanding the implications of the Bill will help students protect their rights to freedom of expression, navigate the new rules on digital conduct, and continue using social media platforms in a responsible and creative way.

Upon hearing the term “Artificial Intelligence,” many immediately picture familiar virtual assistants such as Alexa and Siri, advanced technologies like ChatGPT, or iconic portrayals from movies like The Terminator or TV series such as the Kdrama My Holo Love. These instances often align with a narrow but prevalent perspective on AI, encapsulating contemporary innovations and cultural references that shape the ongoing history of artificial intelligence.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) isn’t merely a futuristic idea confined to sci-fi realms; it’s a pervasive part of our everyday experiences. Whether it’s the personalized recommendations on streaming platforms like Netflix or the optimized routes suggested by ride-sharing services such as Pathao, AI permeates various aspects of modern life.

This intricate ecosystem of interconnected technologies has steadily evolved over decades, contributing to its current complexity and ubiquity. Understanding the history of AI unveils a layered narrative, showcasing the diverse tools and capabilities that have molded it into the game-changing force it represents today.

Tracing the trajectory of AI’s development is key to comprehending its present importance and preparing for its future implications. By examining its origins and evolutionary path, we gain valuable insights into how AI has transformed from a conceptual idea into a transformative technology that profoundly influences our daily routines and shapes industries across the spectrum. grasping the past paves the way for harnessing the potential of AI in our ever-evolving world.

AI’s origins lie within the academic halls of prestigious university research departments, initially pondered by scholars envisioning computing’s future. However, its infancy tethered it to these domains, hampered by scarce data and limited computational prowess.

A pivotal moment arose in 1956 at Dartmouth College, where the renowned Dartmouth Summer Research Project on Artificial Intelligence convened. This workshop aimed to validate the notion that machines could simulate learning with precision—a groundbreaking hypothesis explored by 20 researchers.

In subsequent years, significant strides marked AI’s trajectory. American psychologist Frank Rosenblatt’s perceptron algorithm, born from Dartmouth’s research, demonstrated successful binary classification, offering glimpses into artificial neurons’ learning potential. Concurrently, John McCarthy, an attendee of the Dartmouth project, along with MIT students, pioneered Lisp, a novel programming language laying the groundwork for future advancements like the SHRDLU natural language program and others.

The 1960s witnessed the emergence of Simulmatics, a company claiming to predict voting patterns based on demographics. By 1965, “expert systems” surfaced, allowing AI to tackle specialized problems using factual databases and inference engines. MIT professor Joseph Weizenbaum’s Eliza in 1966 showcased AI’s intelligence by engaging users as pseudo-therapists, responding to their inputs with open-ended questions.

However, by the mid-1970s, dwindling faith in AI among governments and corporations led to funding shortages, marking the onset of the “AI winter.” Despite brief revivals in the 1980s and 1990s, AI remained largely relegated to science fiction, steering clear of serious computer science discourse.

It wasn’t until the late 1990s and early 2000s that AI saw widespread adoption of machine learning techniques, including Bayesian methods from spam filtering by Microsoft and collaborative filtering for Amazon recommendations, marking a resurgence in AI’s practical applications.

During the 2000s, a confluence of factors, including increased computing power, expansive datasets, and the ascent of open-source software, empowered developers to engineer advanced algorithms. This technological wave promised swift and transformative change across scientific, consumer, manufacturing, and business sectors within a remarkably brief period. Today, AI is an integral part of numerous business operations, attaining tangible reality.

For instance, McKinsey’s research highlights a staggering 400 instances where companies actively leverage AI to tackle various business challenges. These real-world applications of AI exemplify its widespread adoption and effectiveness in addressing multifaceted business issues.

Likewise, in the early to mid-2000s web revolution introduced significant changes to AI research. Foundational technologies like Extensible Markup Language (XML) and Google’s PageRank altered data organization, facilitating AI integration.

XML played a crucial role in shaping the semantic web and bolstering search engine capabilities, while PageRank redefined web organization. These innovations enhanced data accessibility for AI, rendering vast amounts of information more navigable.

Simultaneously, database improvements in data storage and retrieval, alongside advancements in functional programming languages, streamlined data manipulation for developers and researchers. These combined tools provided a fertile ground for advancing AI technology.

AI held ambitious promises throughout the 20th century, yet limited computing power posed significant barriers to realizing these ambitions. However, as the 21st century dawned, computers underwent an exponential surge in capability, becoming proficient in storing, processing, and analyzing massive volumes of data. This paradigm shift paved the way for translating the ambitious goals of neural networks and deep learning into tangible realities.

Researchers made strides by curating datasets explicitly tailored for machine training, culminating in the creation of neural networks like AlexNet. Unlike earlier methods reliant on datasets numbering in the tens of thousands, advancements in graphics processing units (GPUs) allowed for datasets to reach tens of millions, significantly enhancing machine learning capabilities.

In 2006, Nvidia, a leading computer chip manufacturer, introduced CUDA, a parallel computing platform that harnessed the power of GPUs to drastically accelerate computational speeds. This monumental leap facilitated the execution of large, intricate machine-learning models through platforms such as TensorFlow and PyTorch, propelling innovation in the field.

As these platforms evolved into open-source libraries, they democratized AI, enabling widespread experimentation. This democratization empowered the inception and growth of groundbreaking tools like AlphaGo, Google DeepMind, and IBM Deep Blue, fostering an era of exciting advancements in artificial intelligence.

The journey through the history of artificial intelligence, from its academic origins to its practical applications in the 21st century, is a testament to the relentless pursuit of innovation. As we trace AI’s evolution, we witness a remarkable narrative of perseverance, breakthroughs, setbacks, and resurgence. From the constrained academic domains of the past to the wide-scale adoption in enterprises today, AI’s story reflects not just technological advancement but also the human endeavor to push boundaries and harness the potential of evolving technologies.

The vibrant tapestry of AI’s history sets the stage for an even more promising future, where the fusion of human ingenuity and cutting-edge technology continues to reshape industries, revolutionize problem-solving, and redefine our interaction with the world. As we stand on the precipice of unparalleled advancements, the legacy of AI’s history guides us, offering invaluable insights into the past and serving as a beacon to navigate the limitless possibilities that lie ahead in the dynamic landscape of artificial intelligence.

In today’s hyper-connected digital landscape, the evolution of technology has brought about both opportunities and challenges. With the proliferation of devices and the exponential growth of data, ensuring robust network security has become a critical concern for individuals, businesses, and industries worldwide. Among the myriad tools available to fortify network security, the role of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in network security emerges as a pivotal game-changer. AI presents multifaceted solutions, spanning from fraud detection to enhancing telecom infrastructure through edge computing, significantly shaping the landscape of AI in network security.

Within the ever-shifting terrain of cybersecurity, safeguarding sensitive information and infrastructure is paramount, and network security serves as its foundational bastion. Artificial Intelligence (AI) has emerged as a formidable ally in strengthening network security, offering sophisticated tools and capabilities to swiftly and accurately detect, prevent, and counter cyber threats, thereby fortifying defenses against evolving dangers.

AI-powered systems leverage machine learning algorithms to analyze vast amounts of data in real-time. This analysis helps identify patterns, anomalies, and potential threats that traditional rule-based systems might miss. AI systems, drawing from history, adapt to new threats to detect and prevent cyber-attacks proactively, averting significant damage.

AI’s strength lies in its ability to discern normal patterns of behavior within a network. By continuously analyzing network activities and user behaviors, AI can detect deviations that signal potential security breaches. Behavioral analytics powered by AI assist in distinguishing between legitimate user actions and malicious intent, enabling swift responses to mitigate risks.

One of AI’s primary advantages in network security is its capacity for rapid response and adaptation. These systems can autonomously respond to security incidents in real-time. By employing predictive analysis and predefined response protocols, AI can contain threats, minimizing their impact while continuously evolving to counter new and emerging threats effectively.

AI-driven cybersecurity tools excel in identifying sophisticated threats such as zero-day attacks, polymorphic malware, and advanced persistent threats (APTs). Through deep learning techniques, AI systems can analyze complex data structures like network traffic and system logs, uncovering subtle indicators of potential threats that evade traditional security measures.

AI automation streamlines routine security tasks, enabling cybersecurity professionals to focus on strategic initiatives. Automated processes in threat detection, incident response, and vulnerability management significantly enhance efficiency and reduce response times, which is crucial in the rapidly evolving threat landscape.

As cyber threats continue to evolve in complexity and frequency, the integration of AI in network security remains pivotal. The ongoing advancements in AI technologies, including machine learning, deep learning, and neural networks, promise further innovations in fortifying network defenses and ensuring the resilience of critical infrastructure.

AI’s role in network security will continue to evolve, offering enhanced capabilities in threat detection, incident response, and predictive analytics. Adapting AI-driven solutions will be essential for organizations seeking robust defenses against the ever-adapting landscape of cyber threats, ensuring the protection of valuable data and infrastructure in an increasingly interconnected digital world.

Telecommunication networks face the challenge of handling vast amounts of data while ensuring low latency and high-speed connectivity. AI’s integration with edge computing has emerged as a transformative solution, revolutionizing telecom infrastructure in the following ways:

Telecom operators can optimize network performance by deploying AI algorithms at the network edge. AI-driven analytics predict network congestion, dynamically allocate resources, and optimize bandwidth, ensuring seamless connectivity even in high-demand scenarios.

With AI, Edge computing enables real-time data analysis closer to the source, reducing latency significantly. This is crucial for applications like autonomous vehicles, IoT devices, and smart cities that require instantaneous decision-making capabilities.

AI-integrated edge devices can bolster security by detecting and mitigating threats at the network’s edge. These systems can identify anomalies in network traffic, secure endpoints, and prevent potential breaches, enhancing overall network security.

Therefore, combining Artificial Intelligence with network security and telecom infrastructure has heralded a new era of proactive defense mechanisms and optimized performance. AI’s ability to learn, adapt, and respond in real-time empowers industries to stay ahead in the ongoing battle against cyber threats. Furthermore, its integration with edge computing not only fortifies network security but also lays the foundation for a more efficient, responsive, and interconnected digital ecosystem.

As technology continues to evolve, the utilization of AI in network security will remain pivotal in safeguarding sensitive information, maintaining robust infrastructure, and enabling the seamless operation of the interconnected world we live in. Embracing the power of AI in network security is not merely an option; it’s a necessity in the digital age.

In today’s competitive job market, LinkedIn stands out as a powerful ally for professionals and students. Often misconceived as solely a platform for seasoned professionals, LinkedIn is equally beneficial for students in paving their way toward successful career paths. Remarkably, data reveals that 98% of recruiters and 85% of hiring managers actively utilize LinkedIn as their primary tool for identifying and engaging potential candidates. Therefore,  leveraging the power of LinkedIn can significantly boost your chances of landing your dream job. Hence, in this blog, you can discover how you can make your LinkedIn profile better and transform your profile presence into a powerful asset for career advancement for both, professionals and students!

LinkedIn serves as a dynamic platform connecting millions of professionals worldwide, offering invaluable resources for job seekers. Through its extensive network, users can explore job listings, connect with recruiters, and gain insights for career advancement.

Additionally, LinkedIn allows individuals to showcase their expertise, skills, and accomplishments, serving as a virtual resume that can attract potential employers. Therefore, optimizing your profile is crucial in making a lasting impression and increasing your visibility to recruiters and hiring managers. To empower your profile and amplify its impact within this expansive platform, here are ten strategic tips curated to elevate your LinkedIn presence and open doors to new professional horizons.

Select a professional and clear profile picture where your face is easily visible. A high-quality image with appropriate attire and a friendly yet professional demeanor can create a positive first impression.
Showcase your educational background, certifications, courses, and any academic achievements. This gives visitors a quick overview of your qualifications and expertise.
Describe your work experiences, internships, and any significant projects undertaken. Emphasize key responsibilities, achievements, and skills gained during these roles.
Utilize the skills section to list your competencies. Incorporate industry-related keywords and relevant abilities to increase visibility and showcase your expertise.

Developing a strong personal brand is integral to career progression. LinkedIn serves as an ideal platform to cultivate a compelling professional brand. By sharing relevant content, contributing to discussions, and showcasing expertise, individuals can solidify their reputation as industry leaders.
Connect with colleagues, classmates, mentors, and professionals from your field. Expanding your network broadens opportunities for collaboration, knowledge sharing, and potential job prospects.
Personalize connection requests when reaching out to professionals. Explain your intent behind the connection and how you may be able to mutually benefit from the connection.

Incorporate industry-specific keywords throughout your profile, including in your headline, summary, experience descriptions, and skill section. This optimization helps improve your profile’s visibility in searches.

Actively engage with recruiters and HR professionals in your field. Building relationships with them can increase your visibility for job opportunities and keep you informed about industry trends and openings.
Join industry-related groups and participate in discussions. Sharing insightful content or engaging in discussions can demonstrate your expertise and expand your network.

Regularly update your profile with new skills, experiences, achievements, and any professional development activities. Engage with connections and stay current with industry news and trends by sharing and interacting with relevant content.

It is essential to enhance your LinkedIn profile, a necessity not only for professionals but also for students seeking to chart a successful career path. These proactive efforts are designed to enhance their prospects of securing desirable job placements. In today’s world, we are witnessing an unprecedented surge in data generation. This data serves as the lifeblood for businesses, fueling their growth and development. Data scientists use various tools and techniques, including data analysis, machine learning, and data visualization, to transform raw data into actionable knowledge.

Therefore, data science is an excellent career choice for individuals looking to make a tangible impact through data-driven decision-making. The AI revolution is sweeping the world, and Nepal is no exception. As artificial intelligence continues to reshape industries and create new opportunities, the demand for skilled AI professionals in Nepal is skyrocketing. These professionals are at the forefront of innovation and enjoy some of the most attractive salaries in the job market. In this blog, we’ll explore some of the highest-paying AI jobs in Nepal, shedding light on the lucrative opportunities that await talented individuals in this dynamic field.

AI’s impact on Nepal’s job market cannot be underestimated. It is both transforming existing roles and ushering in entirely new career opportunities. To succeed in this field, individuals must acquire advanced skills and knowledge, making it clear that AI is not merely trivial programming. A solid educational background and training are prerequisites, alongside proficiency in computer science and programming.

Without a doubt, AI is synonymous with high-paying jobs. AI professionals are highly sought after in today’s job market, and their salaries reflect the value they bring to the industry. The demand for AI experts has driven up compensation, making AI one of the most financially rewarding career paths in Nepal.
Following are the top high-salary AI jobs in Nepal, attracting talent from all over the country and promising a prosperous future for venturing into the world of artificial intelligence.

Salary in Nepal: Machine Learning Engineers in Nepal can expect to earn between NPR 100,000 to NPR 400,000 per month. For seasoned professionals with substantial experience, the salary can go beyond NPR 600,000.

Machine Learning Engineers play a pivotal role in AI development by creating and implementing machine learning algorithms and models. This task involves training, which is a high processor and computation-intensive aspect of machine learning. Given the complexity of this work, it demands the highest level of skill and training. Most Machine Learning Engineers hold advanced degrees in computer science, mathematics, or statistics. They often pursue further training through certification programs or master’s degrees in areas such as machine learning, deep learning, or neural networks.
Salary in Nepal: Data Scientists in Nepal can earn between NPR 150,000 to NPR 300,000 per month, with experienced professionals commanding higher salaries.

Data Scientists are technology professionals who specialize in collecting, analyzing, and interpreting data to solve problems and drive decision-making within organizations. While not all are programmers, many write their applications. They frequently employ data mining, big data tools, and analytical techniques. Their insights derived from data help businesses improve sales, and operations, make informed decisions, and develop new products and services. Predictive modeling and data visualization are part of their toolkit, with some using machine learning to automate these tasks.
Salary in Nepal: Data Engineers or Architects in Nepal typically earn between NPR 180,000 and NPR 350,000 per month.

Data Engineers work with massive data sets, a fundamental aspect of AI. They are responsible for designing, building, testing, and maintaining complex data processing systems. These professionals typically work with big data tools like Hadoop, Hive, Spark, and Kafka. Advanced degrees in mathematics and statistics are often prerequisites for these roles, as they are crucial for designing, maintaining, and building data pipelines based on extensive data sets.
Salary in Nepal: Software Engineers with AI skills in Nepal can expect monthly earnings ranging from NPR 120,000 to NPR 250,000, depending on experience and expertise.

Software Engineers in the AI domain are responsible for various activities in the software development chain, including design, development, testing, and deployment. AI Software Engineers design, develop, test, and deploy applications related to machine learning, inference, natural language processing (NLP), sensory input, cybersecurity, and intrusion detection.
Salary in Nepal: AI Research Scientists in Nepal can command monthly salaries ranging from NPR 250,000 to NPR 500,000 or more.

AI Research Scientists are computer scientists who specialize in studying and developing new AI algorithms and techniques. Their work involves developing and testing new AI models, collaborating with other researchers, publishing research papers, and presenting findings at conferences. While programming is a component of their work, a significant portion of their role involves research and innovation. AI Research Scientists typically hold graduate degrees and have a strong background in computer science, mathematics, and statistics.

The average salary of an AI professional is subject to various factors that significantly impact earnings. Education, experience, geographic location, industry, and the specific job role all contribute to determining one’s income in this field.

Notably, experience stands out as one of the most influential elements affecting salary levels. The logic is simple: the more experience you accumulate as an AI engineer, the deeper your expertise becomes, and consequently, the higher your earning potential in this dynamic and evolving industry.

AI isn’t merely a good career; it’s a future-proof one. As AI continues to shape the world, the demand for AI professionals will only continue to grow. A career in AI offers high earning potential, job security, and the opportunity to contribute to the future of technology.

Sunway College Kathmandu recognizes the importance of bringing up talent in this field, offering programs such as “Data Science and Artificial Intelligence” and “BSc (Hons) Computer Science with AI” that ensure students are well-prepared for the exciting journey that lies ahead.

Upon hearing the term “Artificial Intelligence,” many immediately picture familiar virtual assistants such as Alexa and Siri, advanced technologies like ChatGPT, or iconic portrayals from movies like The Terminator or TV series such as the Kdrama My Holo Love. These instances often align with a narrow but prevalent perspective on AI, encapsulating contemporary innovations and cultural references that shape the ongoing history of artificial intelligence.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) isn’t merely a futuristic idea confined to sci-fi realms; it’s a pervasive part of our everyday experiences. Whether it’s the personalized recommendations on streaming platforms like Netflix or the optimized routes suggested by ride-sharing services such as Pathao, AI permeates various aspects of modern life.

This intricate ecosystem of interconnected technologies has steadily evolved over decades, contributing to its current complexity and ubiquity. Understanding the history of AI unveils a layered narrative, showcasing the diverse tools and capabilities that have molded it into the game-changing force it represents today.

Tracing the trajectory of AI’s development is key to comprehending its present importance and preparing for its future implications. By examining its origins and evolutionary path, we gain valuable insights into how AI has transformed from a conceptual idea into a transformative technology that profoundly influences our daily routines and shapes industries across the spectrum. grasping the past paves the way for harnessing the potential of AI in our ever-evolving world.

AI’s origins lie within the academic halls of prestigious university research departments, initially pondered by scholars envisioning computing’s future. However, its infancy tethered it to these domains, hampered by scarce data and limited computational prowess.

A pivotal moment arose in 1956 at Dartmouth College, where the renowned Dartmouth Summer Research Project on Artificial Intelligence convened. This workshop aimed to validate the notion that machines could simulate learning with precision—a groundbreaking hypothesis explored by 20 researchers.

In subsequent years, significant strides marked AI’s trajectory. American psychologist Frank Rosenblatt’s perceptron algorithm, born from Dartmouth’s research, demonstrated successful binary classification, offering glimpses into artificial neurons’ learning potential. Concurrently, John McCarthy, an attendee of the Dartmouth project, along with MIT students, pioneered Lisp, a novel programming language laying the groundwork for future advancements like the SHRDLU natural language program and others.

The 1960s witnessed the emergence of Simulmatics, a company claiming to predict voting patterns based on demographics. By 1965, “expert systems” surfaced, allowing AI to tackle specialized problems using factual databases and inference engines. MIT professor Joseph Weizenbaum’s Eliza in 1966 showcased AI’s intelligence by engaging users as pseudo-therapists, responding to their inputs with open-ended questions.

However, by the mid-1970s, dwindling faith in AI among governments and corporations led to funding shortages, marking the onset of the “AI winter.” Despite brief revivals in the 1980s and 1990s, AI remained largely relegated to science fiction, steering clear of serious computer science discourse.

It wasn’t until the late 1990s and early 2000s that AI saw widespread adoption of machine learning techniques, including Bayesian methods from spam filtering by Microsoft and collaborative filtering for Amazon recommendations, marking a resurgence in AI’s practical applications.

During the 2000s, a confluence of factors, including increased computing power, expansive datasets, and the ascent of open-source software, empowered developers to engineer advanced algorithms. This technological wave promised swift and transformative change across scientific, consumer, manufacturing, and business sectors within a remarkably brief period. Today, AI is an integral part of numerous business operations, attaining tangible reality.

For instance, McKinsey’s research highlights a staggering 400 instances where companies actively leverage AI to tackle various business challenges. These real-world applications of AI exemplify its widespread adoption and effectiveness in addressing multifaceted business issues.

Likewise, in the early to mid-2000s web revolution introduced significant changes to AI research. Foundational technologies like Extensible Markup Language (XML) and Google’s PageRank altered data organization, facilitating AI integration.

XML played a crucial role in shaping the semantic web and bolstering search engine capabilities, while PageRank redefined web organization. These innovations enhanced data accessibility for AI, rendering vast amounts of information more navigable.

Simultaneously, database improvements in data storage and retrieval, alongside advancements in functional programming languages, streamlined data manipulation for developers and researchers. These combined tools provided a fertile ground for advancing AI technology.

AI held ambitious promises throughout the 20th century, yet limited computing power posed significant barriers to realizing these ambitions. However, as the 21st century dawned, computers underwent an exponential surge in capability, becoming proficient in storing, processing, and analyzing massive volumes of data. This paradigm shift paved the way for translating the ambitious goals of neural networks and deep learning into tangible realities.

Researchers made strides by curating datasets explicitly tailored for machine training, culminating in the creation of neural networks like AlexNet. Unlike earlier methods reliant on datasets numbering in the tens of thousands, advancements in graphics processing units (GPUs) allowed for datasets to reach tens of millions, significantly enhancing machine learning capabilities.

In 2006, Nvidia, a leading computer chip manufacturer, introduced CUDA, a parallel computing platform that harnessed the power of GPUs to drastically accelerate computational speeds. This monumental leap facilitated the execution of large, intricate machine-learning models through platforms such as TensorFlow and PyTorch, propelling innovation in the field.

As these platforms evolved into open-source libraries, they democratized AI, enabling widespread experimentation. This democratization empowered the inception and growth of groundbreaking tools like AlphaGo, Google DeepMind, and IBM Deep Blue, fostering an era of exciting advancements in artificial intelligence.

The journey through the history of artificial intelligence, from its academic origins to its practical applications in the 21st century, is a testament to the relentless pursuit of innovation. As we trace AI’s evolution, we witness a remarkable narrative of perseverance, breakthroughs, setbacks, and resurgence. From the constrained academic domains of the past to the wide-scale adoption in enterprises today, AI’s story reflects not just technological advancement but also the human endeavor to push boundaries and harness the potential of evolving technologies.

The vibrant tapestry of AI’s history sets the stage for an even more promising future, where the fusion of human ingenuity and cutting-edge technology continues to reshape industries, revolutionize problem-solving, and redefine our interaction with the world. As we stand on the precipice of unparalleled advancements, the legacy of AI’s history guides us, offering invaluable insights into the past and serving as a beacon to navigate the limitless possibilities that lie ahead in the dynamic landscape of artificial intelligence.
